title: The Study
content: The aim of this intervention was to promote a better QoL for people with dementia using familiar, reminiscent music and the natural gestures of the group of 22 participants to create an original series of dance exercises. Performed over 10 weekly sessions, the study showed that “participants reported significant improvements in their quality of life after session six.”

title: The Weaknesses
content: There was no control group in this study. The study was not randomized. How can we possibly know if any effect, however small, was not more of a result of some other factor associated with being in a study, such as the attention of the investigators? Did you notice that the article stated that participants reported significant improvements in their self-reported QoL after session six, which was 6 weeks into a 10-week study? It turns out that after the 10-weekly sessions, the reported improvements in the QoL of participants were not statistically significant.

title: Study on Music and Dance for Dementia Patients
content: A 10-week pilot study found that self-reported improvements in QoL after 10-weekly sessions of music and dance were not statistically significant. The University of Otago published a press release claiming the positive effects of music and dance on QoL in dementia patients is now proven.

title: The Importance of Doubt in Science
content: In science, it is imperative to doubt and have uncertainty as a fundamental part of your inner nature. To make progress in understanding, we must remain modest and allow that we do not know. Nothing is certain or proved beyond all doubt.
